Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 01:52AM Pam123 wrote: Hey Watson!   I am happy to know that I am not the only one who cries in their car.   I generally prefer the freeway at night.   Its too much work to try and wipe away your tears stopped at a traffic light!  And the Cheetos!   BRILLIANT! I am wishing all the best to you! Viva Cheetos!
Posts.Title: Xeloda Crappola Watson Watson

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 05:39PM Pam123 wrote: Hi Dawn.   I appreciate you sharing your story.   I had a partial mastectomy in 06.   Chemo before and after surgery.   Then radiation.   It was in my pre-radiation xrays that they thought that I had mets in my lungs.   At that point I figured I would quit the radiation because what the radiation was supposed to prevent had already happened.   Of course all physcians wanted me to continue with the only explanation that it was preventing a local recurrence.  I was frustrated but I decided to just play the game.   After a bronchoscopy biopsy of my lungs and then a very invasive open lung biopsy, it was clear that what was happening in my lungs was not cancer.  That was Sept. 07.   Well just like that darn cat that keeps coming back, I grew myself another tumor in my right breast.   A very local recurrence that radiation should've prevented.   I had a mastectomy in February.    After the surgery, my onc ordered a full ctscan to see if the cancer was somewhere else.   A week after the ctscan, driving home from work, I found a lump in my neck.   Talking with my onc about the results of the ctscan, he said that it appeared that I had a tumor in my liver which he said had doubled since last year. ( Funny no one every mention the tumor there last year)   I was a little shocked but then I told him about my neck.  He said that he wouldn't be surprised if it was cancer.   So when I saw him yesterday, he recommended the chemo.  And then dropped the you'll probably have to be on chemo for the rest of your life.   I was a little shocked by that.   I have been trying to figure out if it would be worth the chemo or not.  The dr even said that I will need to get a port, because my veins just won't last. ( the surprises kept coming!)   But let me just say again thank you for sharing your story.   Since my lump showed up, I had been trying to find information about the supraclavicular lyphnode.   Thank you.   I wish you all the best!
